content.verbatim_text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must ensure that all contracts provide maximum flexibility for Zebracorp to assign without supplier consent to any succeeding entity (e.g., in a reorganization) or, at a minimum, allow free assignment to an affiliate.
content.expert_insight: This guideline is critical for Zebracorp's strategic flexibility, enabling seamless corporate reorganizations, acquisitions, or divestitures without being held hostage by supplier consent requirements, which can complicate and sidetrack transactions.
content.conditions: Applies to all contracts Zebracorp concludes.
content.justification: The text explicitly states 'important to make sure' and highlights the critical nature for business transactions, indicating a mandatory and high-impact requirement.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp's ability to restructure or sell parts of its business without contractual impediments or additional costs/delays.
content.implication_supplier: Limits the supplier's control over who Zebracorp's contracting party might become in certain scenarios.
content.source_insight: The guideline provides two tiers of preference: 'maximum flexibility' (no consent for succeeding entity) and 'at the minimum' (free assignment to an affiliate).
content.text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).

content.verbatim_text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.
content.plain_text: If a supplier refuses to grant Zebracorp the right to assign to an affiliate, Zebracorp should, at a minimum, ensure the contract states that approval for assignment will not be arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.
content.expert_insight: This serves as a crucial fallback position, preventing suppliers from using their consent right to extort concessions or unreasonably block legitimate assignments, thereby maintaining a degree of control over the process.
content.conditions: Applies if the supplier refuses to grant free assignment to an affiliate.
content.justification: The phrase 'at the very minimum' indicates a strong preference and a necessary safeguard if the primary objective is not met.
content.implication_company: Provides a legal basis to challenge unreasonable withholding of consent, protecting Zebracorp's ability to assign.
content.implication_supplier: Obligates the supplier to act reasonably and not to impede assignment without valid commercial reasons.
content.source_insight: This is a compromise position when full flexibility (no consent) is not achievable.
content.text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.

content.verbatim_text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's right to assign contracts should explicitly include the right to partially assign the contract, even if this right might be implicitly covered by the right to assign the entire agreement.
content.expert_insight: Explicitly stating the right to partial assignment removes any ambiguity and prevents potential disputes, which is particularly useful in scenarios like divestments where only a portion of a contract's scope might need to be transferred.
content.justification: The text uses 'should include' and 'recommended to expressly agree', indicating a preferred but not strictly mandatory position.
content.implication_company: Enhances Zebracorp's flexibility in managing contracts during business reorganizations or divestments.
content.implication_supplier: Clarifies the scope of Zebracorp's assignment rights, potentially requiring the supplier to manage a split contract.
content.source_insight: Acknowledges that partial assignment might be implicit but advises explicit agreement for clarity.
content.text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially.

content.verbatim_text: Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should ideally seek to secure a right to 'split' contracts in the event of a divestment of a Zebracorp business line, ensuring both Zebracorp and the acquirer can continue to use the relevant contract.
content.expert_insight: This right is highly valuable for preserving the operational continuity and value of divested business lines, preventing the need to renegotiate or replicate contracts, which can be costly and time-consuming.
content.conditions: Applies in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line.
content.justification: The term 'ideally we should also seek' indicates a strong preference and a strategic objective.
content.implication_company: Facilitates smoother divestments and ensures continued access to critical contracts for both Zebracorp and the acquirer.
content.implication_supplier: Requires the supplier to accommodate the splitting of a contract, potentially leading to two separate contractual relationships.
content.source_insight: This is a specific type of assignment right tailored for divestment scenarios.
content.text: Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.

content.verbatim_text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent.
content.plain_text: When negotiating assignment clauses, Zebracorp must not agree to a mutual assignment right that allows suppliers to freely assign the agreement to a third party without Zebracorp's consent. Zebracorp would rather forego its own assignment right than grant such a right to a supplier.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical risk mitigation strategy. Allowing suppliers to freely assign negates Zebracorp's rigorous selection process, potentially exposing Zebracorp to financially or operationally incapable third parties and enabling suppliers to evade critical commitments.
content.conditions: Applies when negotiating assignment clauses with suppliers/subcontractors.
content.justification: The text uses 'would not wish to agree' and 'would rather forego... than to agree', emphasizing a firm, non-negotiable stance due to significant risks.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from unknown or unsuitable third-party suppliers and ensures continuity of service/quality from vetted partners.
content.implication_supplier: Restricts the supplier's ability to transfer its contractual obligations without Zebracorp's approval.
content.source_insight: Highlights the asymmetric nature of the customer-supplier relationship and the importance of supplier vetting.
content.text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent.

content.verbatim_text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's right to assign a contract must not be made subject to Zebracorp remaining jointly liable with the assignee. The assignment must be unconditional, providing a clean exit where Zebracorp is not liable for assignee commitments and does not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement.
content.expert_insight: This is paramount for liability management. Remaining jointly liable after assignment defeats the purpose of transferring obligations and exposes Zebracorp to risks from parties it no longer controls. A clean exit is essential for risk mitigation.
content.justification: The text uses 'should not be made subject to' and 'will not accept liability', indicating a firm, non-negotiable requirement for Zebracorp's protection.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp is fully released from contractual obligations and liabilities post-assignment, providing a clean break.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier's recourse for performance or liability shifts entirely to the assignee post-assignment.
content.source_insight: Emphasizes the 'unconditional' nature of the assignment and the concept of a 'clean exit' for Zebracorp.
content.text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's firm view is that assignment of contracts by operation of law should not require supplier consent. Zebracorp should reject any contractual language that mandates seeking consent for such transfers.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical stance to prevent significant complications, delays, and potential deal-breaking issues during mergers, acquisitions, or other corporate transactions where contracts transfer automatically by law.
content.justification: The text states 'Zebracorp’s firm view' and 'should reject any language', indicating a non-negotiable policy due to the high impact on corporate transactions.
content.implication_company: Facilitates smooth and timely corporate transactions (M&A) by avoiding the need for numerous individual contract consents.
content.implication_supplier: Limits the supplier's ability to object to or leverage a change in Zebracorp's ownership structure.
content.source_insight: Highlights the practical difficulties and impact on timing/cost if consent is required for assignments by operation of law.
content.text: Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law.

content.verbatim_text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract.
content.plain_text: In critical R&D contracts where Zebracorp imposes assignment restrictions on suppliers, it is preferable to abandon the entire assignment clause rather than agreeing to a mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp's own assignment rights.
content.expert_insight: This prioritizes Zebracorp's strategic flexibility over controlling supplier assignments in specific, sensitive contract types. It acknowledges that mutual restrictions could be more detrimental to Zebracorp than the benefit of restricting the supplier.
content.conditions: Applies to critical R&D contracts where Zebracorp imposes assignment restrictions on suppliers.
content.justification: The phrase 'it would be better to abandon' indicates a strong preference and a strategic decision to avoid a worse outcome.
content.implication_company: Maintains Zebracorp's flexibility for assignment, even if it means losing the ability to restrict supplier assignments in certain cases.
content.implication_supplier: May result in suppliers having more freedom to assign in R&D contracts if Zebracorp abandons the clause.
content.source_insight: Illustrates a pragmatic approach to negotiation where Zebracorp's own flexibility is paramount.
content.text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract.

content.verbatim_text: In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: To make contracts more acceptable to suppliers, Zebracorp can agree to allow suppliers to transfer contracts by operation of law, provided the transferee is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This offers a reasonable compromise that addresses supplier concerns about their own corporate restructuring while safeguarding Zebracorp's competitive interests by preventing transfers to direct rivals.
content.conditions: Applies when making contracts more palatable to suppliers regarding assignment by operation of law.
content.justification: The phrase 'we can make the contract more palatable' suggests a negotiable option rather than a strict requirement.
content.implication_company: Balances supplier relations with competitive protection.
content.implication_supplier: Gains some flexibility for assignment by operation of law, subject to not transferring to a Zebracorp competitor.
content.source_insight: A practical negotiation tactic to achieve a mutually acceptable outcome.
content.text: In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement. Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team to obtain the appropriate templates/language.
content.plain_text: When an agreement is governed by UK laws, Zebracorp should specifically ensure the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, as the transfer of both rights and obligations typically requires a specific novation agreement. Consult Legal & Compliance for appropriate templates/language.
content.expert_insight: Under UK law, assignment typically only transfers benefits, not burdens. Novation is essential for a complete transfer of both, ensuring Zebracorp is fully released from obligations and avoids residual liability. This is a critical legal distinction.
content.conditions: Applies when the agreement is governed by UK laws.
content.justification: The text states 'it is useful to specifically mention' and advises consulting Legal & Compliance, indicating a crucial legal requirement for proper transfer under UK law.
content.implication_company: Ensures proper legal transfer of both benefits and burdens, mitigating residual liability under UK law.
content.implication_supplier: Requires the supplier to agree to a novation, formally releasing Zebracorp and accepting the new party.
content.source_insight: Highlights the specific legal requirements for transferring contracts under UK jurisdiction, distinguishing assignment from novation.
content.text: For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement. Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team to obtain the appropriate templates/language.

content.verbatim_text: Accordingly, there is no need to seek or grant consent to such change of name/registered address alone. A unilateral notification of the name change to the other contracting party should be sufficient.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp does not need to seek or grant consent for a change of company name or registered address, provided the underlying legal entity remains the same. A unilateral notification to the other contracting party is sufficient.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies that administrative changes do not constitute an assignment requiring consent, streamlining internal processes and avoiding unnecessary bureaucratic hurdles.
content.conditions: Applies when only the company name or registered address changes, and the underlying legal entity remains the same.
content.justification: The text explicitly states 'there is no need to seek or grant consent' and 'should be sufficient', indicating a clear rule for administrative changes.
content.implication_company: Simplifies administrative updates, avoiding the need for formal consent processes.
content.implication_supplier: Requires the supplier to acknowledge a unilateral notification of name/address change.
content.source_insight: Distinguishes between a change in legal entity (assignment) and a mere change in name/address.
content.text: Accordingly, there is no need to seek or grant consent to such change of name/registered address alone. A unilateral notification of the name change to the other contracting party should be sufficient.

content.verbatim_text: Except as otherwise provided in this [Agreement], neither party may assign, novate, delegate, or transfer this [Agreement], or any of its individual rights or obligations under this [Agreement], without the prior written approval of the other Party, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld or delayed.
content.plain_text: Generally, neither Zebracorp nor the supplier may assign, novate, delegate, or transfer the agreement or its rights/obligations without the other party's prior written approval, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld or delayed.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a standard baseline for assignment control, ensuring that any transfer by either party is subject to a reasonable consent process. However, Zebracorp's specific carve-outs (below) are more critical for its strategic flexibility.
content.conditions: Unless otherwise specifically provided in the agreement.
content.justification: This is presented as the general default rule in Zebracorp's preferred clause, indicating a standard commercial term.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must seek consent for assignments not covered by its specific carve-outs, but consent cannot be unreasonably withheld.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier must seek consent for assignments, and Zebracorp cannot unreasonably withhold it.
content.source_insight: This is the general rule, which is then immediately followed by Zebracorp's specific exceptions.
content.text: Except as otherwise provided in this [Agreement], neither party may assign, novate, delegate, or transfer this [Agreement], or any of its individual rights or obligations under this [Agreement], without the prior written approval of the other Party, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld or delayed.

content.verbatim_text: However, [Zebracorp] may, without the prior written consent of the [Supplier], unconditionally assign, novate, delegate or transfer any or all of its rights and obligations under this [Agreement], in whole, in part, or through a splitting of the [Agreement], to any Affiliate or to any acquirer of a Zebracorp business line to which this contract relates.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp may, without the supplier's prior written consent, unconditionally assign, novate, delegate, or transfer any or all of its rights and obligations (in whole, in part, or by splitting the agreement) to any Affiliate or any acquirer of a Zebracorp business line to which the contract relates.
content.expert_insight: This is the cornerstone of Zebracorp's assignment strategy, providing maximum flexibility for internal reorganizations, M&A activities, and divestitures without requiring burdensome and potentially costly supplier consents.
content.justification: This is explicitly stated as a 'However' clause to the general rule, granting Zebracorp a specific, unconditional right that is paramount for its business operations.
content.implication_company: Grants Zebracorp broad, unconditional rights to transfer contracts for strategic business purposes.
content.implication_supplier: Obligates the supplier to accept such transfers without prior consent, potentially dealing with a new Zebracorp entity or an acquirer.
content.source_insight: This is the key exception to the general mutual consent rule, reflecting Zebracorp's preferred position.
content.text: However, [Zebracorp] may, without the prior written consent of the [Supplier], unconditionally assign, novate, delegate or transfer any or all of its rights and obligations under this [Agreement], in whole, in part, or through a splitting of the [Agreement], to any Affiliate or to any acquirer of a Zebracorp business line to which this contract relates.

content.verbatim_text: As of the effective date of the assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer, the assignee entity(ies) assumes all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement], and [Zebracorp] is unconditionally released and discharged from all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement].
content.plain_text: Upon the effective date of any assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer, the assignee entity(ies) assumes all relevant rights, obligations, and liabilities of the agreement, and Zebracorp is unconditionally released and discharged from all relevant rights, obligations, and liabilities.
content.expert_insight: This is crucial for liability mitigation, ensuring Zebracorp achieves a 'clean exit' and is not burdened with ongoing liabilities for contracts it has transferred, which is a fundamental risk management principle.
content.conditions: As of the effective date of the assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer.
content.justification: The text uses 'unconditionally released and discharged', indicating a non-negotiable and high-impact requirement for Zebracorp's protection.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp has no residual liability for assigned contracts.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier's contractual counterparty and the party responsible for obligations shifts entirely to the assignee.
content.source_insight: Reinforces the 'clean exit' principle discussed earlier in the document.
content.text: As of the effective date of the assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer, the assignee entity(ies) assumes all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement], and [Zebracorp] is unconditionally released and discharged from all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement].

content.verbatim_text: [Supplier] will work cooperatively with [Zebracorp] and the assignee entity(ies) to ensure a smooth and orderly transition.
content.plain_text: The supplier will work cooperatively with Zebracorp and the assignee entity(ies) to ensure a smooth and orderly transition following an assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer.
content.expert_insight: This clause ensures practical support from the supplier during the transition, minimizing disruption and facilitating business continuity for Zebracorp and its assignees.
content.conditions: Following an assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer.
content.justification: The use of 'will work cooperatively' indicates a clear obligation on the supplier to facilitate the process, which is highly desirable for Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Ensures the supplier's active participation in making the assignment process efficient.
content.implication_supplier: Obligates the supplier to provide reasonable assistance during the transition period.
content.source_insight: A practical clause to ensure the operational aspects of an assignment are handled effectively.
content.text: [Supplier] will work cooperatively with [Zebracorp] and the assignee entity(ies) to ensure a smooth and orderly transition.

content.verbatim_text: Assignment clauses can become critical in a sale of business, acquisition or other similar transaction. Having an obligation to obtain consents for assigning contracts from present contract parties can complicate and potentially sidetrack the contemplated transaction. Failure to pay close attention to the language of the assignment clause while the contract is being negotiated may also create an opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions in return to its consent to the contract assignment.
content.plain_text: Assignment clauses are crucial in M&A transactions. Requiring consent for assignment can complicate or derail a deal. Neglecting the assignment clause during negotiation can lead to the other party demanding concessions for their consent later.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the strategic importance of proactive negotiation of assignment clauses. A poorly drafted clause can become a significant leverage point for the counterparty during future corporate events, leading to unexpected costs or delays.
content.justification: Provides general background information and explains the strategic importance and potential risks associated with assignment clauses in M&A contexts.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must prioritize careful negotiation of assignment clauses to avoid future complications, delays, and potential extortion during M&A or reorganization events.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may gain leverage if Zebracorp's assignment clause is restrictive, allowing them to demand concessions for consent during Zebracorp's corporate transactions.
content.source_insight: The text implicitly suggests that understanding these risks should drive Zebracorp's negotiation strategy.
content.text: Assignment clauses can become critical in a sale of business, acquisition or other similar transaction. Having an obligation to obtain consents for assigning contracts from present contract parties can complicate and potentially sidetrack the contemplated transaction. Failure to pay close attention to the language of the assignment clause while the contract is being negotiated may also create an opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions in return to its consent to the contract assignment.

content.verbatim_text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's contracts should allow maximum flexibility for assignment without supplier consent, especially to succeeding entities in a reorganization or to affiliates, to facilitate future corporate restructuring.
content.expert_insight: This is a core strategic objective for Zebracorp: ensuring business continuity and flexibility for M&A or internal reorganizations without being beholden to supplier consent, which can be a bottleneck.
content.justification: This is a direct instruction on a key negotiation goal for Zebracorp regarding assignment flexibility.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should actively negotiate for broad assignment rights, particularly to affiliates and successors, to maintain operational and strategic flexibility for future corporate actions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will be asked to grant Zebracorp broad assignment rights without their consent, which might be a point of negotiation, especially if they value the specific counterparty.
content.source_insight: The 'minimum' fallback position suggests a tiered approach to negotiation goals.
content.text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).

content.verbatim_text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.
content.plain_text: If a supplier refuses free assignment to an affiliate, Zebracorp should at least ensure the clause states that any required approval for assignment will not be 'arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed'.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial fallback position. While not as ideal as free assignment, the 'not unreasonably withheld' standard provides a legal basis to challenge arbitrary refusals and maintains some degree of control over the assignment process.
content.justification: This provides a specific fallback negotiation strategy if the primary goal of free assignment is not achieved.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should push for this 'reasonableness' standard as a minimum safeguard against arbitrary supplier actions, ensuring a path for assignment even if consent is required.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may be asked to accept a 'not unreasonably withheld' standard, limiting their discretion in approving assignments, which is a common commercial compromise.
content.source_insight: This demonstrates a pragmatic approach to negotiation, setting clear minimum acceptable terms.
content.text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.

content.verbatim_text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially. Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should explicitly negotiate for the right to partially assign contracts, even if it's often implicit. Ideally, it should also secure the right to 'split' contracts during business line divestments, allowing both Zebracorp and the acquirer to continue using the contract.
content.expert_insight: Explicitly stating partial assignment and contract splitting rights provides clarity and prevents disputes, especially critical for complex divestitures where specific business lines need to carry over relevant contracts. This foresight protects Zebracorp's divestment strategy.
content.justification: This outlines specific negotiation objectives for Zebracorp to ensure maximum flexibility in contract management during corporate restructuring.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure its assignment clauses explicitly cover partial assignments and contract splitting to facilitate future divestments and maintain business continuity.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may face requests for more granular assignment rights, including partial assignment and contract splitting, which could add complexity to their contract management.
content.source_insight: The recommendation to 'expressly agree' highlights a best practice over relying on implicit rights.
content.text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially. Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.

content.verbatim_text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent. This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should avoid mutual assignment rights with suppliers. It would rather give up its own assignment right than allow a supplier to freely assign the contract without Zebracorp's consent. This is because Zebracorp's supplier selection process ensures specific capabilities, and free assignment by suppliers would undermine this, potentially leading to critical commitments being unmet.
content.expert_insight: This is a strong strategic stance reflecting Zebracorp's customer position. It prioritizes control over supplier identity and performance, recognizing the inherent risk of a supplier substituting itself with an unvetted third party. This non-mutuality is a key negotiation point.
content.justification: This is a clear instruction on Zebracorp's negotiation stance regarding mutual assignment rights and the underlying rationale.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must firmly resist mutual assignment clauses, even if it means sacrificing some of its own assignment flexibility, to protect its interests in supplier quality and reliability.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will likely face resistance from Zebracorp if they propose mutual assignment rights, as Zebracorp prioritizes maintaining control over who performs the supplier's obligations.
content.source_insight: The justification provided (supplier selection process) is a strong argument to use in negotiations.
content.text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent. This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.

content.verbatim_text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's assignment rights should ensure it is not jointly liable with the assignee for the assigned contract. The assignment must be unconditional, providing a clean exit for Zebracorp from all relevant rights, obligations, and liabilities.
content.expert_insight: This is critical for liability management. Zebracorp seeks a complete transfer of obligations and liabilities, not just rights, to avoid residual exposure after an assignment. This 'clean exit' is a non-negotiable point for risk mitigation.
content.justification: This is a direct instruction on a key negotiation goal for Zebracorp to limit its post-assignment liability.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure assignment clauses explicitly release it from all liabilities post-assignment, preventing any ongoing or joint liability with the assignee.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will be expected to accept Zebracorp's full release from liability upon assignment, meaning they will look solely to the assignee for performance and liability.
content.source_insight: The emphasis on 'unconditional' and 'clean exit' highlights the importance of this point for Zebracorp.
content.text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.

content.verbatim_text: In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent.
content.plain_text: When a company is acquired via a share purchase (making it a subsidiary), there's generally no need for contract assignment consent because the legal entity holding the contracts remains the same; only its ownership changes. This contradicts a common misconception.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies a fundamental legal principle regarding corporate acquisitions. Understanding this distinction is vital for M&A planning, as it can significantly reduce the administrative burden and potential roadblocks associated with obtaining numerous contract consents.
content.justification: Provides crucial legal context and corrects a common misconception regarding assignment by operation of law in share acquisitions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can structure acquisitions via share purchases to avoid the need for contract-by-contract assignment consents, streamlining M&A processes.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that a change in ownership of Zebracorp (via share purchase) does not typically trigger assignment consent rights, unless explicitly stated in the contract.
content.source_insight: The phrase 'Contrary to widely held belief' emphasizes the educational nature of this information.
content.text: In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent.

content.verbatim_text: An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party. The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent.
content.plain_text: In most countries, acquisitions or mergers automatically transfer (vest) assets, liabilities, and contracts to the new or surviving entity by 'operation of law', without requiring consent from the other contracting party. However, parties can contractually agree that a significant ownership change (e.g., over 50% shares) will require consent.
content.expert_insight: This explains the default legal position for statutory mergers/acquisitions and highlights the contractual override. Zebracorp needs to be mindful of these contractual overrides, especially in supplier templates, as they can negate the benefits of 'operation of law' transfers.
content.justification: Explains the legal principle of assignment by operation of law and notes how it can be contractually modified.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can generally rely on automatic vesting in mergers/acquisitions, but must carefully review contracts for clauses that override this default by requiring consent for ownership changes.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can, through specific contractual language, impose consent requirements for changes of control, even if not required by general law.
content.source_insight: The distinction between default law and contractual freedom is important for negotiation strategy.
content.text: An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party. The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent.

content.verbatim_text: Also, clauses that prohibit any transfer by any kind of merger or "change of control" are not uncommon. Below is an example of such clause: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”. Variants of the above provision can be found in particular in suppliers’ own contract templates.
content.plain_text: Clauses prohibiting transfers via merger or 'change of control' are common, especially in supplier templates. An example is: 'Any attempted assignment... by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent'.
content.expert_insight: This warns Zebracorp about prevalent restrictive clauses, particularly in supplier-drafted agreements. Recognizing these 'change of control' provisions is the first step in negotiating them away or mitigating their impact.
content.justification: Provides an example of a common restrictive clause that Zebracorp will encounter, along with context about its prevalence.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must be vigilant in identifying and negotiating against these types of clauses in supplier contracts, as they can severely restrict its M&A flexibility.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers often include these clauses to maintain control over who they contract with, especially in cases of change of control or merger.
content.source_insight: The note about 'suppliers’ own contract templates' indicates where Zebracorp is most likely to encounter these clauses.
content.text: Also, clauses that prohibit any transfer by any kind of merger or "change of control" are not uncommon. Below is an example of such clause: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”. Variants of the above provision can be found in particular in suppliers’ own contract templates.

content.verbatim_text: While we may want to restrict the supplier from changing ownership or control without our approval, Zebracorp is often not itself willing to agree to such restrictions. Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law. This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions.
content.plain_text: While Zebracorp may want to restrict suppliers from changing ownership without its approval, Zebracorp is generally unwilling to accept similar restrictions on itself. Zebracorp's firm position is that assignment by operation of law should not require supplier consent, and it should reject such language, as these provisions complicate M&A transactions.
content.expert_insight: This highlights Zebracorp's asymmetric negotiation stance, leveraging its position as a customer. It's a clear directive to prioritize Zebracorp's M&A flexibility over reciprocal restrictions, recognizing the practical difficulties these clauses create.
content.justification: This outlines Zebracorp's firm negotiation position and the strategic rationale for rejecting certain restrictive clauses, especially concerning assignment by operation of law.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must consistently reject clauses requiring consent for assignment by operation of law to preserve its M&A flexibility and avoid transactional complications.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will find Zebracorp resistant to 'change of control' clauses that would restrict Zebracorp's ability to assign by operation of law, even if Zebracorp imposes similar restrictions on them.
content.source_insight: The 'firm view' indicates a strong, non-negotiable position for Zebracorp.
content.text: While we may want to restrict the supplier from changing ownership or control without our approval, Zebracorp is often not itself willing to agree to such restrictions. Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law. This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions.

content.verbatim_text: For example, if Zebracorp was planning on forming a merger with another company, we would work from the assumption that our contracts with our suppliers/subcontractors would be automatically transferred to the new merged entity by operation of law without the need seek consents from our supplier base. An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction.
content.plain_text: For instance, in a merger, Zebracorp assumes its contracts will automatically transfer by operation of law without supplier consent. Restrictive assignment clauses would negatively impact the timing, cost, and smoothness of such a merger.
content.expert_insight: This example illustrates the practical implications of restrictive clauses. It underscores the need to proactively address assignment terms to avoid future M&A hurdles, emphasizing the 'cost of friction' in corporate transactions.
content.justification: Provides a concrete example of how assignment restrictions can complicate Zebracorp's M&A activities.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's M&A strategy relies on the assumption of automatic contract transfer; restrictive clauses directly threaten the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of these transactions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers imposing such restrictions might inadvertently complicate Zebracorp's corporate transactions, potentially leading to renegotiations or delays.
content.source_insight: The example reinforces the 'why' behind Zebracorp's negotiation stance.
content.text: For example, if Zebracorp was planning on forming a merger with another company, we would work from the assumption that our contracts with our suppliers/subcontractors would be automatically transferred to the new merged entity by operation of law without the need seek consents from our supplier base. An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction.

content.verbatim_text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: For critical R&D contracts where Zebracorp restricts supplier assignment, it's preferable to remove the clause entirely rather than making it mutual and restricting Zebracorp. This non-mutuality can be justified by the customer-supplier asymmetry. To make it more acceptable, Zebracorp can allow suppliers to transfer by operation of law to non-competitors.
content.expert_insight: This provides advanced negotiation tactics for specific, sensitive contracts. It shows a willingness to sacrifice a desired restriction on suppliers if the alternative is a mutual restriction on Zebracorp. The 'asymmetric relationship' and 'non-competitor' carve-out are valuable arguments and concessions.
content.justification: This provides specific, nuanced negotiation tactics for critical contracts, including a fallback position and a potential concession strategy.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be prepared to drop restrictive clauses on suppliers in critical contracts if mutuality is demanded, and use the customer-supplier dynamic or non-competitor carve-out as negotiation tools.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers might be able to negotiate for less restrictive assignment clauses, especially if they are willing to accept a 'non-competitor' limitation for transfers by operation of law.
content.source_insight: This demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of negotiation leverage and strategic trade-offs.
content.text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract. Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation. For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement. Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team to obtain the appropriate templates/language.
content.plain_text: Under UK law, assignment typically only transfers benefits. To transfer both benefits and burdens (and avoid residual liability), a novation is usually required. For UK-governed agreements, explicitly state that the agreement is both assigned and novated, and a specific novation agreement may be needed. Consult Legal & Compliance for templates.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical legal distinction for contracts governed by UK law. Failing to novate when intending to transfer both benefits and burdens can leave Zebracorp with residual liability. The instruction to consult Legal & Compliance is a standard internal process for specialized legal matters.
content.justification: Provides specific legal guidance and an internal process instruction for handling assignments under UK law.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must be aware of the specific requirements for transferring contracts under UK law, ensuring proper novation to avoid residual liabilities, and should engage legal counsel for this.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers dealing with Zebracorp under UK law will need to understand the distinction between assignment and novation, and may be asked to execute novation agreements.
content.source_insight: The instruction to 'speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team' indicates the complexity and need for expert advice.
content.text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract. Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation. For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement. Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team to obtain the appropriate templates/language.

content.verbatim_text: Due to the prevalence of UK origin contract documentation, the term novation and novation agreements in general are often (incorrectly) used in other jurisdictions as well when the parties should be talking about contract transfer or assignment. This in itself is not issue in the majority of cases, as most jurisdictions will recognize the term novation to mean the same as transfer of a contract.
content.plain_text: The term 'novation' is often incorrectly used in non-UK jurisdictions when 'contract transfer' or 'assignment' is more appropriate, due to UK contract documentation prevalence. However, this is usually not an issue as most jurisdictions interpret 'novation' as a general contract transfer.
content.expert_insight: This provides useful context on common terminology pitfalls. While it notes that the incorrect usage is often harmless, it's good practice to use precise terminology relevant to the governing law to avoid any potential ambiguity or misinterpretation.
content.justification: Provides general information about common terminology usage and its practical implications across jurisdictions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be aware of the precise legal meaning of 'novation' versus 'assignment' based on governing law, but can be somewhat reassured that common misusage often doesn't lead to major issues.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers might use 'novation' broadly, and Zebracorp should understand that in many jurisdictions, this will be interpreted as a general contract transfer.
content.source_insight: The 'incorrectly used' but 'not issue in the majority of cases' highlights a practical reality over strict legal precision.
content.text: Due to the prevalence of UK origin contract documentation, the term novation and novation agreements in general are often (incorrectly) used in other jurisdictions as well when the parties should be talking about contract transfer or assignment. This in itself is not issue in the majority of cases, as most jurisdictions will recognize the term novation to mean the same as transfer of a contract.

content.verbatim_text: Companies have the freedom to change the trade name that they use to conduct their business. When changing the name of the company, the registered legal entity which can be identified through each company’s individual registration number remains the same. These type of changes in the name or registered addresses of a company are not regarded as assignments so long as the underlying legal entity remains the same and only the name/address of the company changes. Accordingly, there is no need to seek or grant consent to such change of name/registered address alone. A unilateral notification of the name change to the other contracting party should be sufficient. While it is recommended to clarify the name change in future contract amendments, strictly speaking this is not necessary. The name change can be mentioned in a contract amendment in e.g. by adding a following note in brackets after the name of the contracting party: e.g. “(formerly known as Zebracorp Space)” or, in short, “(f/k/a Zebracorp Space)”.
content.plain_text: Changing a company's trade name or registered address is not considered an assignment if the underlying legal entity (identified by its registration number) remains the same. Therefore, consent is not required; a unilateral notification is sufficient. While clarifying in future amendments is recommended, it's not strictly necessary. An example notation is '(formerly known as Zebracorp Space)' or '(f/k/a Zebracorp Space)'.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies a common point of confusion. It's important for Zebracorp to understand that simple name/address changes do not trigger assignment clauses, avoiding unnecessary administrative burden and potential disputes. The recommended notation is a practical tip for clarity.
content.justification: Provides clear information and practical instructions regarding company name/address changes and their non-impact on assignment clauses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can change its name or address without needing consent from contract parties, only requiring notification, which simplifies administrative processes.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should understand that Zebracorp's name or address changes do not constitute an assignment requiring their consent.
content.source_insight: The distinction between legal entity and trade name is key here.

These type of changes in the name or registered addresses of a company are not regarded as assignments so long as the underlying legal entity remains the same and only the name/address of the company changes. Accordingly, there is no need to seek or grant consent to such change of name/registered address alone. A unilateral notification of the name change to the other contracting party should be sufficient. While it is recommended to clarify the name change in future contract amendments, strictly speaking this is not necessary. The name change can be mentioned in a contract amendment in e.g. by adding a following note in brackets after the name of the contracting party: e.g. “(formerly known as Zebracorp Space)” or, in short, “(f/k/a Zebracorp Space)”.

content.verbatim_text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract.

content.verbatim_text: Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation.
content.plain_text: To transfer both benefits and burdens of a contract without residual liability, especially under UK law, a novation is generally required.
content.expert_insight: This explains the primary function of novation: to fully substitute one party for another, releasing the original party from liability.

content.verbatim_text: “Except as otherwise provided in this [Agreement], neither party may assign, novate, delegate, or transfer this [Agreement], or any of its individual rights or obligations under this [Agreement], without the prior written approval of the other Party, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. Any attempted assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer without the necessary approval is void. However, [Zebracorp] may, without the prior written consent of the [Supplier], unconditionally assign, novate, delegate or transfer any or all of its rights and obligations under this [Agreement], in whole, in part, or through a splitting of the [Agreement], to any Affiliate or to any acquirer of a Zebracorp business line to which this contract relates. As of the effective date of the assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer, the assignee entity(ies) assumes all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement], and [Zebracorp] is unconditionally released and discharged from all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement]. [Supplier] will work cooperatively with [Zebracorp] and the assignee entity(ies) to ensure a smooth and orderly transition.”
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's preferred assignment clause mandates mutual prior written approval for general assignments (not unreasonably withheld or delayed), with any unapproved attempt being void. Crucially, Zebracorp retains the unconditional right to assign, novate, delegate, or transfer all or part of its rights and obligations, including splitting the agreement, to any Affiliate or acquirer of a relevant business line without supplier consent. Upon such transfer, the assignee assumes all relevant rights, obligations, and liabilities, and Zebracorp is unconditionally released. The supplier must cooperate for a smooth transition.
content.expert_insight: This comprehensive preferred clause encapsulates Zebracorp's strategic objectives: maintaining general control over assignments while securing maximum unilateral flexibility for its own corporate restructuring (affiliates, divestments) and ensuring a clean exit from liability.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: This clause reflects Zebracorp's preferred position to ensure maximum flexibility for its own corporate transactions and liability mitigation, while providing a baseline for general assignment consent.
content.implication_company: Grants Zebracorp significant flexibility for internal reorganizations, acquisitions, and divestments without needing supplier consent, and ensures a full release from liabilities post-assignment.
content.implication_supplier: Requires supplier to grant consent for general assignments (not unreasonably withheld). For Zebracorp's assignments to affiliates or business line acquirers, no supplier consent is needed, and the supplier must cooperate with the new entity. Supplier loses recourse against Zebracorp post-assignment.
